llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.
> Quote: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
> Reasoning: The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol, which was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews.
> Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.
> Quote: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences were resolved by discussion."
> Reasoning: Two investigators assessed the titles and extracted data independently, and any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator.
> Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).
> Quote: "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospitali ischaemic bowel, complications). Hand searches of the references for selected papers were carried out to identify additional relevant studies."
> Reasoning: The review searched at least two electronic sources (Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar) and supplemented the search by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.
> Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.
> Quote: "There were no restrictions made on the basis of study language or geographical location. Studies were included if they comprised the following participants and interventions, and at least one of the outcomes of interest."
> Reasoning: The review did not restrict the search based on publication status, language, or geographical location.
> Response: [Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.
> Quote: "There were 751 unique articles remaining. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria."
> Reasoning: The review provided a list of included studies.
> Response: [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.
> Quote: "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR."
> Reasoning: The review provided the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated form.
> Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).
> Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The review assessed and documented the scientific quality of the included studies using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria.
> Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.
> Quote: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
> Reasoning: The review considered the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating conclusions.
> Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.
> Quote: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout."
> Reasoning: The review used appropriate methods to combine the findings of studies and assessed their homogeneity.
> Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.
> Quote: "Statistical analysis Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The review assessed the likelihood of publication bias using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria.
> Response: [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.
> Quote: "Funding: Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorhip. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http://www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
> Reasoning: The review clearly acknowledged potential sources of support in both the systematic review and the included studies.
> Response: [Yes]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
> Quote: "Challenges of Improving the Evidence Base in Smaller Surgical Specialties, as Highlighted by a Systematic Review of Gastroschisis Management"
> Reasoning: The report is identified as a systematic review in the title.
> Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
> Quote: "Objective: To identify methods of improving the evidence base in smaller surgical specialties, using a systematic review of gastroschisis management as an example. Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed comparing outcomes following OPFC and SR in infants with simple gastroschisis. Results: 751 unique articles were identified. Eight met the inclusion criteria. None were randomized controlled trials. 488 infants underwent OPFC and 316 underwent SR. Length of stay was significantly longer in the SR group (mean difference 8.97 days, 95% CI 2.1415.80 days), as was number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding (mean difference 7.19 days, 95%CI 2.01--12.36 days). Mortality was not statistically significantly different, although the odds of death were raised in the SR group (OR 1.96, 95%CI 0.71--5.35). Conclusions: Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported. Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
> Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings.
> Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> Quote: "With variation existing around the specifics of management of some of the most common neonatal surgical conditions including oesophageal atresia, gastroschisis and Hirschsprungs disease, research should be commonplace. Yet despite these fertile conditions for research, for these three conditions, only fourteen prospectively registered clinical trials and two systematic reviews could be identified on a search of the major registries at the time of writing."
> Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
> Quote: "Using a systematic review and meta-analysis of gastroschisis as an example, we aimed to highlight some of the key challenges in paediatric surgical research, and suggest ways in which the strength of our clinical evidence base could be improved."
> Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
> Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
> Quote: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
> Reasoning: The methods indicate that a review protocol exists and provide registration information including the registration number.
> Response: [Yes]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
> Quote: "Studies were included if they comprised the following participants and interventions, and at least one of the outcomes of interest. Participants: Studies were included if they involved infants born with simple gastroschisis, defined as gastroschisis with an intact continuous bowel that is not compromised or breached at delivery or presentation. Interventions: The intervention of interest was SR, defined as use of a silo (pre-formed, custom or improvised) for staged reduction of the abdominal viscera, followed by any form of defect closure. The comparator intervention, OPFC was defined as primary reduction of the abdominal viscera, with sutured closure of the fascial layers under general anaesthesia with-out prior placement of a silo. Outcomes: Primary outcome measures: 1. Mortality 2. Length of hospital stay 3. Time to complete enteral feeding/duration of parenteral feeding Secondary outcome measures: 1. Duration of ventilator use 2. Infective complication 3. Perforation 4. Ischaemic bowel 5. Necrotising Enterocolitis (NEC) 6. Anastomotic stricture 7. Adhesional small bowel obstruction 8. Complications related to stoma 9. Short bowel syndrome 10. Liver disease associated with intestinal failure"
> Reasoning: The methods specify study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
> Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
> Quote: "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospitali ischaemic bowel, complications). Hand searches of the references for selected papers were carried out to identify additional relevant studies."
> Reasoning: The methods describe all information sources in the search and the date last searched.
> Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
> Quote: "Not applicable in this text."
> Reasoning: The methods do not present the full electronic search strategy for at least one database.
> Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
> Quote: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences were resolved by discussion."
> Reasoning: The methods state the process for selecting studies.
> Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
> Quote: "Data were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences were resolved by discussion."
> Reasoning: The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports.
> Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
> Quote: "Not applicable in this text."
> Reasoning: The methods do not list and define all variables for which data were sought.
> Response: [No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
> Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The methods describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
> Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
> Quote: "Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
> Reasoning: The methods state the principal summary measures.
> Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.
> Quote: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout."
> Reasoning: The methods describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
> Response: [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
> Quote: "Statistical analysis Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The methods specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
> Response: [Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
> Quote: "Not applicable in this text."
> Reasoning: The methods do not describe methods of additional analyses.
> Response: [No]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
> Quote: "Using the stated search strategy, 3081 papers were identified. After removal of duplicates, 751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria."
> Reasoning: The results give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.
> Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
> Quote: "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR."
> Reasoning: The results present characteristics for which data were extracted for each study.
> Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
> Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The results present data on risk of bias of each study.
> Response: [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
> Quote: "Length of stay was significantly longer in the SR group (mean difference 8.97 days, 95% CI 2.14--15.80 days), as was number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding (mean difference 7.19 days, 95%CI 2.01--12.36 days). Mortality was not statistically significantly different, although the odds of death were raised in the SR group (OR 1.96, 95%CI 0.71--5.35)."
> Reasoning: The results present, for each study, simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates and confidence intervals.
> Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
> Quote: "Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
> Reasoning: The results present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
> Response: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
> Quote: "Statistical analysis Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The results specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
> Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).
> Quote: "Not applicable in this text."
> Reasoning: The results do not give results of additional analyses.
> Response: [No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
> Quote: "Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported. Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
> Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
> Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
> Quote: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
> Reasoning: The discussion discusses limitations at study and outcome level.
> Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
> Quote: "Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
> Reasoning: The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
> Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
> Quote: "Funding: Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorhip. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http://www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
> Reasoning: The funding describes sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
> Response: [Yes]
original_llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.
> Quote: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
> Reasoning: The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol, which was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews.
> Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.
> Quote: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences were resolved by discussion."
> Reasoning: Two investigators assessed the titles and extracted data independently, and any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator.
> Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).
> Quote: "Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospitali ischaemic bowel, complications). Hand searches of the references for selected papers were carried out to identify additional relevant studies."
> Reasoning: The review searched at least two electronic sources (Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar) and supplemented the search by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.
> Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.
> Quote: "There were no restrictions made on the basis of study language or geographical location. Studies were included if they comprised the following participants and interventions, and at least one of the outcomes of interest."
> Reasoning: The review did not restrict the search based on publication status, language, or geographical location.
> Response: [Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.
> Quote: "There were 751 unique articles remaining. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria."
> Reasoning: The review provided a list of included studies.
> Response: [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.
> Quote: "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR."
> Reasoning: The review provided the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated form.
> Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).
> Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The review assessed and documented the scientific quality of the included studies using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria.
> Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.
> Quote: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
> Reasoning: The review considered the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating conclusions.
> Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.
> Quote: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout."
> Reasoning: The review used appropriate methods to combine the findings of studies and assessed their homogeneity.
> Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.
> Quote: "Statistical analysis Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
> Reasoning: The review assessed the likelihood of publication bias using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria.
> Response: [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.
> Quote: "Funding: Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorhip. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http://www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
> Reasoning: The review clearly acknowledged potential sources of support in both the systematic review and the included studies.
> Response: [Yes]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
> Quote: "Challenges of Improving the Evidence Base in Smaller Surgical Specialties, as Highlighted by a Systematic Review of Gastroschisis Management"
> Reasoning: The report is identified as a systematic review in the title.
> Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
> Quote: "Objective: To identify methods of improving the evidence base in smaller surgical specialties, using a systematic review of gastroschisis management as an example. Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed comparing outcomes following OPFC and SR in infants with simple gastroschisis. Results: 751 unique articles were identified. Eight met the inclusion criteria. None were randomized controlled trials. 488 infants underwent OPFC and 316 underwent SR. Length of stay was significantly longer in the SR group (mean difference 8.97 days, 95% CI 2.1415.80 days), as was number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding (mean difference 7.19 days, 95%CI 2.01--12.36 days). Mortality was not statistically significantly different, although the odds of death were raised in the SR group (OR 1.96, 95%CI 0.71--5.35). Conclusions: Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported. Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
> Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and implications of key findings.
> Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> Quote: "With variation existing around the specifics of management of some of the most common neonatal surgical conditions including oesophageal atresia, gastroschisis and Hirschsprungs disease, research should be commonplace. Yet despite these fertile conditions for research, for these three conditions, only fourteen prospectively registered clinical trials and two systematic reviews could be identified on a search of the major registries at the time of writing."
> Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
> Quote: "Using a systematic review and meta-analysis of gastroschisis as an example, we aimed to highlight some of the key challenges in paediatric surgical research, and suggest ways in which the strength of our clinical evidence base could be improved."
> Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
> Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
> Quote: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

> Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
> Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
> Quote: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
> Reasoning: The discussion discusses limitations at study and outcome level.
> Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
> Quote: "Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
> Reasoning: The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
> Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
> Quote: "Funding: Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorhip. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http://www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
> Reasoning: The funding describes sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
> Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a yes.

* Quote: "This review will aid pediatric surgeons in making management decisions when faced with a recurrent TEF."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that an 'a priori' design was provided, but the objective of the review is clearly stated, indicating that the research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that there were at least two independent data extractors, but it does mention that multiple databases and journals were searched, and the reference lists of all relevant articles were also searched, indicating that some level of duplicate study selection and data extraction was performed.
* Response: [NA]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The review mentions that multiple electronic databases were searched, but it does not provide the specific search strategy or keywords used. However, it does mention that the reference lists of all relevant articles were also searched, indicating that some level of comprehensive literature search was performed.
* Response: [NA]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

* Quote: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The review states that all English language articles published by August 2013 were reviewed, indicating that the status of publication was used as an inclusion criterion and that reports were included regardless of their publication type.
* Response: [Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* Quote: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS."
* Reasoning: The review provides a list of included studies, but it does not explicitly state that a list of excluded studies was provided.
* Response: [NA]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* Quote: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS."
* Reasoning: The review provides some characteristics of the included studies, but it does not provide a table or a detailed description of the participants, interventions, and outcomes.
* Response: [NA]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* Quote: "The outcomes after these two repairs are summarized in Tables 1-4. Overall, of the 57 patients managed using a variety of ETs there was an 84% (n = 48) success rate compared with 93.5% (n = 101) of 108 patients that had OS. Of the seven failed OS cases, three patients that died in the immediate postoperative period were considered treatment failures. One patient went on to have a cervical esophagostomy followed by gastric transposition, another two underwent an esophagectomy and gastric transposition each, and one had an unspecified esophageal replacement."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that the scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented, but it does provide some information about the outcomes of the studies, indicating that some level of assessment was performed.
* Response: [NA]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.

* Quote: "In conclusion, based on our findings on 165 published cases, OS for the repair of recurrent TEF has a low morbidity, mortality, and re-fistulation rate particularly when an interposition tissue is placed between the trachea and esophagus. We recommend OS as the treatment of choice when faced with a recurrent TEF. Endoscopic treatments are a viable alternative in experienced centers with selected cases. Treatment failures after ETs should be anticipated and a systematic approach to the follow-up of these patients is required to promptly diagnose re-fistulation."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that the scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions, but it does provide some recommendations based on the findings of the review.
* Response: [NA]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not include a meta-analysis, so the methods used to combine the findings of studies are not applicable.
* Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not include a meta-analysis, so the likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
* Response: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.

* Quote: "Conflict of Interest None."
* Reasoning: The review explicitly states that there is no conflict of interest.
* Response: [Yes]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* Quote: "Management of RTEF: A Systematic Review"
* Reasoning: The title of the review clearly identifies it as a systematic review.
* Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The abstract of the review provides some information about the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions, but it does not provide a structured summary including all the required elements.
* Response: [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* Quote: "The spectrum of esophageal atresia (EA) and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) include an isolated EA, EA with a proximal and/or distal TEF and the H or N type fistula. Since the initial description of the open surgical repair and subsequent thoracoscopic approaches, the outcomes have been very encouraging. Anastomotic leaks, esophageal strictures, gastric esophageal reflux, and tracheomalacia are complications pediatric surgeons are familiar with. The incidence of a fistula recurrence range from 1.9 to 11% after open and thoracoscopic repairs. The diagnosis of these recurrent tracheoesophageal fistulas (RTEF) can often be elusive to the unsuspecting physician and the ideal approach to their management is still in debate. Proponents of an endoscopic approach to this problem frequently state that the morbidity, mortality, and second recurrence rate are too high with an open approach and majority directly or indirectly reference only literature review of open surgery (OS) from 1970 by Kafrouni et al. Here, we reviewed the published treatment options, and their outcomes, for managing RTEF. This review will aid pediatric surgeons in making management decisions when faced with a recurrent TEF."
* Reasoning: The introduction of the review provides a clear rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
* Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* Quote: "A literature search was performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. All English language articles describing the management of RTEF in children were reviewed. A synthesis of the relevant data is presented in a descriptive form due to the heterogeneity of the included articles."
* Reasoning: The introduction of the review provides an explicit statement of the questions being addressed, but it does not explicitly state the PICOS elements.
* Response: [NA]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not mention the existence of a review protocol or registration information.
* Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The methods section of the review provides some information about the study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, but it does not explicitly state the PICOS elements or give a rationale for the criteria used.
* Response: [NA]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The methods section of the review describes the information sources used in the search and the date last searched.
* Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not provide the full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used.
* Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* Quote: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS."
* Reasoning: The methods section of the review does not explicitly state the process for selecting studies.
* Response: [No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not provide information about the method of data extraction from reports or any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
* Response: [No]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* Reasoning: The review does not provide information about the variables for which data were sought or any assumptions and simplifications made.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* Reasoning: The review does not provide information about the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies or how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

* Quote: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS."

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

* Quote: "This review will aid pediatric surgeons in making management decisions when faced with a recurrent TEF."

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that there were at least two independent data extractors, but it does mention that multiple databases and journals were searched, and the reference lists of all relevant articles were also searched, indicating that some level of duplicate study selection and data extraction was performed.
* Response: [NA]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The review mentions that multiple electronic databases were searched, but it does not provide the specific search strategy or keywords used. However, it does mention that the reference lists of all relevant articles were also searched, indicating that some level of comprehensive literature search was performed.
* Response: [NA]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

* Quote: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of design, describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
* Reasoning: The review states that all English language articles published by August 2013 were reviewed, indicating that the status of publication was used as an inclusion criterion and that reports were included regardless of their publication type.
* Response: [Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* Quote: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS."
* Reasoning: The review provides a list of included studies, but it does not explicitly state that a list of excluded studies was provided.
* Response: [NA]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* Quote: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS."
* Reasoning: The review provides some characteristics of the included studies, but it does not provide a table or a detailed description of the participants, interventions, and outcomes.
* Response: [NA]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* Quote: "The outcomes after these two repairs are summarized in Tables 1-4. Overall, of the 57 patients managed using a variety of ETs there was an 84% (n = 48) success rate compared with 93.5% (n = 101) of 108 patients that had OS. Of the seven failed OS cases, three patients that died in the immediate postoperative period were considered treatment failures. One patient went on to have a cervical esophagostomy followed by gastric transposition, another two underwent an esophagectomy and gastric transposition each, and one had an unspecified esophageal replacement."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that the scientific quality of the included studies was assessed and documented, but it does provide some information about the outcomes of the studies, indicating that some level of assessment was performed.
* Response: [NA]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.

* Quote: "In conclusion, based on our findings on 165 published cases, OS for the repair of recurrent TEF has a low morbidity, mortality, and re-fistulation rate particularly when an interposition tissue is placed between the trachea and esophagus. We recommend OS as the treatment of choice when faced with a recurrent TEF. Endoscopic treatments are a viable alternative in experienced centers with selected cases. Treatment failures after ETs should be anticipated and a systematic approach to the follow-up of these patients is required to promptly diagnose re-fistulation."
* Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state that the scientific quality of the included studies was used appropriately in formulating conclusions, but it does provide some recommendations based on the findings of the review.
* Response: [NA]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not include a meta-analysis, so the methods used to combine the findings of studies are not applicable.
* Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The review does not include a meta-analysis, so the likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
* Response: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.

* Quote: "Conflict of Interest None."
* Reasoning: The review explicitly states that there is no conflict of interest.
* Response: [Yes]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* Quote: "Management of RTEF: A Systematic Review"
* Reasoning: The title of the review clearly identifies it as a systematic review.
* Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* Quote: Not applicable.
* Reasoning: The abstract of the review provides some information about the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions, but it does not provide a structured summary including all the required elements.
* Response: [No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* Quote: "The spectrum of esophageal atresia (EA) and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) include an isolated EA, EA with a proximal and/or distal TEF and the H or N type fistula. Since the initial description of the open surgical repair and subsequent thoracoscopic approaches, the outcomes have been very encouraging. Anastomotic leaks, esophageal strictures, gastric esophageal reflux, and tracheomalacia are complications pediatric surgeons are familiar with. The incidence of a fistula recurrence range from 1.9 to 11% after open and thoracoscopic repairs. The diagnosis of these recurrent tracheoesophageal fistulas (RTEF) can often be elusive to the unsuspecting physician and the ideal approach to their management is still in debate. Proponents of an endoscopic approach to this problem frequently state that the morbidity, mortality, and second recurrence rate are too high with an open approach and majority directly or indirectly reference only literature review of open surgery (OS) from 1970 by Kafrouni et al. Here, we reviewed the published treatment options, and their outcomes, for managing RTEF. This review will aid pediatric surgeons in making management decisions when faced with a recurrent TEF."
* Reasoning: The introduction of the review provides a clear rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
* Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* Quote: "A literature search was performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. All English language articles describing the management of RTEF in children were reviewed. A synthesis of the relevant data is presented in a descriptive form due to the heterogeneity of the included articles."

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched.
