llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
> "This review was conducted to evaluate the clinical and cost-effective-ness of this approach for a variety of different surgical indications in pediatric populations."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review, but no protocol or ethics approval was mentioned.
Response: [No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
> "There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on whether there were at least two independent data extractors or a consensus procedure for disagreements.
Response: [No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
> "All available electronic databases including the Brit-ish Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIO-SIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992  2009 for all English and non English language articles."
Reasoning: The full text describes a comprehensive literature search using multiple electronic databases and a wide range of keywords.
Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
> "The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc."
Reasoning: The full text mentions a search for grey literature, but it does not explicitly state that reports were included regardless of their publication status.
Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
> "A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
> "In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported."
Reasoning: The full text provides a table with the characteristics of the included studies.
Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
> "A priori methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable)."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the scientific quality of the included studies.
Response: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
> "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on how the scientific quality of the included studies was used in formulating conclusions.
Response: [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
> "For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on how the findings of studies were combined.
Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
> "An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the likelihood of publication bias.
Response: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
> "Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the conflict of interest.
Response: [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
> "Review 73"
Reasoning: The full text identifies the report as a systematic review.
Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
> "Abstract & Introduction: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations. Method/ Design: A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparo-scopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts. Outcomes of interest were length of stay (LOS), operating room (OR) time, complication rates and total hospital costs; aggregation of outcome rates was performed with the Mantel-Haenszel method. Results: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. LOS was found to be signifi-cantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with a weighted mean difference of  1.44 days, although the OR time was signifi-cantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of + 12.8 min. Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6 % ). Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignifi-cantly increased compared to the open techniques. Conclusion: This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and over-all complication rates. Increased utilization of this approach may prove benefi-cial to pediatric patients."
Reasoning: The full text provides a structured summary with background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions and implications of key findings.
Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
> "Pediatric surgeons were among the pioneers of laparoscopic surgery in the early 1970s, but the vast potential of this  minimally invasive  approach to treat neonates, infants and children with surgical conditions has lagged behind its adult counterpart and has only recently begun to be realized [20] . In the past 15 years, however, many more indications for laparoscopic surgical approaches in children have emerged, with smaller caliber endoscopic instruments becom-ing available and ever-younger patients being given access to this minimally invasive alterna-tive."
Reasoning: The full text describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
> "Introduction & Objectives: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations."
Reasoning: The full text provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design.
Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
> "Methods / Design: A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparo-scopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the review protocol or registration.
Response: [No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
> "Methods / Eligibility criteria: The review focused on three specific procedures for which outcome data exists: Laparoscopic appendectomy, Laparoscopic fundoplication (anti-reflux procedure) and Laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. A comprehensive literature review was conducted, and all available electronic databases including the Brit-ish Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIO-SIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992  2009 for all English and non English language articles."
Reasoning: The full text specifies study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
> "Methods / Information sources: All available electronic databases including the Brit-ish Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIO-SIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992  2009 for all English and non English language articles."
Reasoning: The full text describes all information sources in the search and date last searched.
Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
> "Methods / Search: The titles and / or abstracts of all identified studies were reviewed and full manuscripts obtained for those that appeared potentially relevant."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide the full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used.
Response: [No]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
> "Methods / Study selection: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. These articles were included in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The full text states the process for selecting studies.
Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
> "Methods / Data collection process: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the method of data extraction from reports or any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
Response: [NA]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
> "Methods / Data items: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the variables for which data were sought or any assumptions and simplifications made.
Response: [NA]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
> "Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies or how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
Response: [NA]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
> "Methods / Summary measures: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the principal summary measures.
Response: [NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2 ) for each meta-analysis.
> "Methods / Synthesis of results: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
Response: [NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
> "Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
Response: [NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
> "Methods / Additional analyses: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the methods of additional analyses.
Response: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
> "Results / Study selection: A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria. These articles were included in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The full text provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
> "Results / Study characteristics: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the characteristics for which data were extracted for each study.
Response: [NA]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
> "Results / Risk of bias within studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the risk of bias of each study.
Response: [NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
> "Results / Results of individual studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of individual studies.
Response: [NA]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
> "Results / Synthesis of results: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of each meta-analysis.
Response: [NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (see Item P15).
> "Results / Risk of bias across studies: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
Response: [NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).
> "Results / Additional analysis: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the results of additional analyses.
Response: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
> "Discussion / Summary of evidence: This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and over-all complication rates. Increased utilization of this approach may prove benefi-cial to pediatric patients."
Reasoning: The full text summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
> "Discussion / Limitations: The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the newer MIS/laparoscopic technique. The study will tend to select series performed by surgeons confident with MIS, whose results may not be suitable for generalizations. Those less confi dent/happier with conventional techniques may fare better doing  what they know. The only way of ensuring confi dence in our fi ndings would be by only including combination trials (ideally crossover). Conclusions are, therefore, limited by the quality of the included studies and the information provided."
Reasoning: The full text discusses limitations at study and outcome level and at review-level.
Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
> "Discussion / Conclusions: This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates. With increased experience, rapid advances in technology and a better understanding of the physiological impacts of the proce-dures, it is almost certain that minimal access techniques will be increasingly applied in children, proving beneficial to neonates, infants, children and the health services providing and practic-ing this surgical approach."
Reasoning: The full text provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
> "Funding: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The full text does not provide information on the sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
Response: [NA]

Total hospital costs of the laparoscopic approaches were found to be insignifi-cantly increased compared to the open techniques. Conclusion: This review further supports the use of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three types laparoscopic procedures reviewed resulted in better patient outcomes compared to open procedures, in the form of reduced LOS and over-all complication rates. Increased utilization of this approach may prove benefi-cial to pediatric patients."

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "The number of obese young people continues to rise, with a corresponding increase in extreme obesity and paediatric-adolescent bariatric surgery. We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI separately by surgery type and (iii) report peri-operative complications, co-morbidity resolution and HRQoL."
* The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Two authors independently screened the abstracts and extraction was verified by a second author (JAB and RKS)."
* There were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements.
* [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "A systematic literature search (19552013) was performed to examine adjustable gastric band, sleeve gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or biliopancreatic diversions operations among obese children and adolescents. Change in BMI a year after surgery was meta-analysed using a random effects model."
* The search strategy included at least two electronic sources (EMBASE and Medline) and specified the years and databases used. Keywords and MESH terms were stated, and the search strategy was provided.
* [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "We aimed to systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI separately by surgery type and (iii) report peri-operative complications, co-morbidity resolution and HRQoL."
* The authors did not explicitly state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type, but they did not exclude any reports based on their publication status, language etc.
* [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "A total of 54 papers met the inclusion criteria, representing 23 unique study populations."
* A list of included studies was provided.
* [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "The median number of patients at baseline in each study was 24 (range 10--108). In total, 637 patients were analysed at post-surgery follow-up. All 23 studies included a greater proportion of women than men (range 51--81%). Pre-surgery BMI was similar for surgery types, although was highest in RYGB studies (median pre-surgery BMI in RYGB, AGB and SG: 52.4, 46.1 and 49.6, respectively). Seven RYGB, 11 AGB studies and 3 SG studies were sourced."
* The characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated form.
* [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* "The exact underlying mechanisms of weight loss for each procedure remain unclear and vary by procedure; greater understanding of gut physiology and gut--brain communication have shown that the benefits of bariatric surgery extend beyond food restriction and malabsorption."
* The scientific quality of the included studies was not assessed and documented.
* [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* "Bariatric surgery leads to significant short-term weight loss in obese children and adolescents. However, the risks of complications are not well defined in the literature. Long-term, prospectively designed studies, with clear reporting of complications and co-morbidity resolution, alongside measures of HRQol, are needed to firmly establish the harms and benefits of bariatric surgery in children and adolescents."
* The scientific quality of the included studies was not used appropriately in formulating conclusions.
* [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

* "Mean BMI at baseline ranged from 38.5 to 60.2 kg m-2 (mean 47.9 kg m-2), and at follow-up from 25.2 to 41.5 kg m-2 (mean 34.7 kg m-2). All studies reported decreases in BMI. Findings from the meta-analysis of change in BMI at 12 months post-operatively are shown in Fig. 2. The average weighted mean BMI difference from baseline to 1 year was -13.5 kg m-2 (95% confidence interval [CI] -15.1, -11.9). There was strong evidence of heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 76.1% and P < 0.001), largely because of the differences among surgery types and populations."
* The methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.
* [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

* "Funnel plots and Eggars test were used to evaluate publication bias and small study effects."
* The likelihood of publication bias was assessed.
* [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

* "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review."
* The conflict of interest was not included.
* [No]

AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* "The number of obese young people continues to rise, with a corresponding increase in extreme obesity and paediatric-adolescent bariatric surgery. We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI separately by surgery type and (iii) report peri-operative complications, co-morbidity resolution and HRQoL."
* The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review.
* [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* "Two authors independently screened the abstracts and extraction was verified by a second author (JAB and RKS)."
* There were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements.
* [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* "A systematic literature search (19552013) was performed to examine adjustable gastric band, sleeve gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass or biliopancreatic diversions operations among obese children and adolescents. Change in BMI a year after surgery was meta-analysed using a random effects model."
* The search strategy included at least two electronic sources (EMBASE and Medline) and specified the years and databases used. Keywords and MESH terms were stated, and the search strategy was provided.
* [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* "We aimed to systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI separately by surgery type and (iii) report peri-operative complications, co-morbidity resolution and HRQoL."
* The authors did not explicitly state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type, but they did not exclude any reports based on their publication status, language etc.
* [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* "A total of 54 papers met the inclusion criteria, representing 23 unique study populations."
* A list of included studies was provided.
* [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* "The median number of patients at baseline in each study was 24 (range 10--108). In total, 637 patients were analysed at post-surgery follow-up. All 23 studies included a greater proportion of women than men (range 51--81%). Pre-surgery BMI was similar for surgery types, although was highest in RYGB studies (median pre-surgery BMI in RYGB, AGB and SG: 52.4, 46.1 and 49.6, respectively). Seven RYGB, 11 AGB studies and 3 SG studies were sourced."
* The characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated form.
* [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* "The exact underlying mechanisms of weight loss for each procedure remain unclear and vary by procedure; greater understanding of gut physiology and gut--brain communication have shown that the benefits of bariatric surgery extend beyond food restriction and malabsorption."
* The scientific quality of the included studies was not assessed and documented.
* [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* "Bariatric surgery leads to significant short-term weight loss in obese children and adolescents. However, the risks of complications are not well defined in the literature. Long-term, prospectively designed studies, with clear reporting of complications and co-morbidity resolution, alongside measures of HRQol, are needed to firmly establish the harms and benefits of bariatric surgery in children and adolescents."
* The scientific quality of the included studies was not used appropriately in formulating conclusions.
* [No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

* "Mean BMI at baseline ranged from 38.5 to 60.2 kg m-2 (mean 47.9 kg m-2), and at follow-up from 25.2 to 41.5 kg m-2 (mean 34.7 kg m-2). All studies reported decreases in BMI. * The methods used to combine the findings of studies were appropriate.
* [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

original_llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review.

* Quote: "We reviewed studies published between 1990 and December 2009, searching for 'hypospadias' in MEDLINE/PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science and the Cochrane Library."
* Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are not explicitly stated in the text, but the search strategy is provided, indicating that an 'a priori' design was used.
* Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place.

* Quote: "Three doctors reviewed the abstracts. Articles relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus."
* Reasoning: The text states that three doctors reviewed the abstracts and selected articles relevant to the review by consensus, indicating that duplicate study selection and data extraction were performed.
* Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.

* Quote: "We reviewed studies published between 1990 and December 2009, searching for 'hypospadias' in MEDLINE/PubMed, EMBASE, Web of Science and the Cochrane Library."
* Reasoning: The text states that studies were searched in four electronic databases, and the search terms used are provided.
* Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc.

* Quote: "The search yielded 69 pertinent studies. These studies were generally of low quality (69.5% surgical series)."
* Reasoning: The text states that 69 studies were included in the review, but it does not provide information on the inclusion or exclusion of grey literature.
* Response: [NA]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided.

* Quote: "The search yielded 69 pertinent studies."
* Reasoning: The text states that 69 studies were included in the review, but it does not provide a list of included or excluded studies.
* Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported.

* Quote: "The search yielded 69 pertinent studies. These studies were generally of low quality (69.5% surgical series)."
* Reasoning: The text states that 69 studies were included in the review, but it does not provide information on the characteristics of the studies.
* Response: [No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant.

* Quote: "These studies were generally of low quality (69.5% surgical series)."
* Reasoning: The text states that the studies were generally of low quality, but it does not provide information on the assessment and documentation of the scientific quality of the included studies.
* Response: [No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations.

* Quote: "The present systematic review shows the weak evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias."
* Reasoning: The text states that the evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias is weak, indicating that the scientific quality of the included studies was considered in formulating conclusions.
* Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?).

* Quote: "The present systematic review shows the weak evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias."
* Reasoning: The text states that the evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias is weak, indicating that the methods used to combine the findings of studies were not appropriate.
* Response: [No]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken).

* Quote: "The present systematic review shows the weak evidence backing current management of primary severe hypospadias."
* Reasoning: The text does not provide information on the assessment of publication bias.
* Response: [No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies.

* Quote: "From the Section of Pediatric Urology, Urology Unit, Department of Oncological and Surgical Sciences, University Hospital of Padova, Padua, Italy (MC), and Department of Pediatric Surgery and Urology, Hpital Robert Debr, APHP, University of Paris VII, Ren Diderot, Paris, France (AEl-G)"
* Reasoning: The text states the affiliations of the authors, indicating that potential sources of support are acknowledged.
* Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a yes.

* Quote: "Aim: Transanal endorectal pull-through (TERPT) has become popular for single-stage treatment of Hirschsprung's disease. The benefits of TERPT over the conventional transabdominal approach(TAB)are still unclear. We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB."
* Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are established before the conduct of the review.
* Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
* Reasoning: There were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements.
* Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* Quote: "Abstract: Aim: Transanal endorectal pull-through (TERPT) has become popular for single-stage treatment of Hirschsprung's disease. The benefits of TERPT over the conventional transabdominal approach(TAB)are still unclear. We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB. Methods: Original articles published from 1998 to 2012 were searched from Medline, Embase, and Cochrane databases. Randomized controlled trials (RCT) and observational clinical studies (OCS) comparing TERPT and TAB were included. Outcomes evaluated included operative time, hospital stay and incidence of postoperative incontinence/soiling, constipation and enterocolitis. Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables; pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables. Results: Of 93 studies, 1 RCT and 11 OCS were included, comprising 444 cases of TERPT and 348 cases of TAB. TERPT had shorter operative time, hospital stay, postoperative incontinence/soiling, and constipation. There was no difference in incidence of postoperative enterocolitis. Conclusion: TERPT is superior to TAB in operative time, hospital stay, postoperative incontinence and constipation. However, more randomized controlled trials are necessary to verify the benefit of TERPT for Hirschsprung's disease."
* Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the systematic review and meta-analysis.
* Response: [Yes]

* Quote: "Study (author, year) Study type No. of procedures Preoperative colostomy, no. (%) TERPT procedure Rectosigmoid HD, no. (%) Age at operation (months), mean  SD or mean Follow-up time (months), mean  SD or mean"
* Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are listed and defined.
* Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
* Reasoning: The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.
* Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

* Quote: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables; pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables."
* Reasoning: The principal summary measures are stated.
* Response: [Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

* Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2 ."
* Reasoning: The methods of handling data and combining results of studies are described.
* Response: [Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2 ."
* Reasoning: The assessment of risk of bias across studies is specified.
* Response: [Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

* Quote: "Not applicable"
* Reasoning: The methods of additional analyses are not described.
* Response: [NA]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

* Quote: "Potentially relevant abstracts captured and screened (N = 93) Articles retrieved for more detailed evaluation (N = 18) Abstract excluded because of no comparison of transanal and transabdominal approach (N = 75) Articles included in meta-analysis (N = 12)"
* Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review are given with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
* Response: [Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

* Quote: "Study (author, year) Study type No. of procedures Preoperative colostomy, no. (%) TERPT procedure Rectosigmoid HD, no. (%) Age at operation (months), mean  SD or mean Follow-up time (months), mean  SD or mean"
* Reasoning: The characteristics for which data were extracted are presented for each study.
* Response: [Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

* Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
* Reasoning: The data on risk of bias of each study are presented.
* Response: [Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

* Quote: "TERPT had shorter operative time, hospital stay, postoperative incontinence/soiling, and constipation. There was no difference in incidence of postoperative enterocolitis."
* Reasoning: The simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates are presented for all outcomes considered.
* Response: [Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

* Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2 ."
* Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis are presented with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
* Response: [Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).

* Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2 ."
* Reasoning: The results of any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence are presented.
* Response: [Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression).

* Quote: "Not applicable"
* Reasoning: The results of additional analyses are not given.
* Response: [NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

* Quote: "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality were considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations."
* Reasoning: The main findings are summarized including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
* Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

* Quote: "The review was limited to published studies and no contact with authors was made to obtain unpublished data. Conference abstracts were also excluded."
* Reasoning: The limitations at study and outcome level and at review-level are discussed.
* Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

* Quote: "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality were considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations."
* Reasoning: The general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.
* Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

* Quote: "Not applicable"
* Reasoning: The sources of funding for the systematic review and other support are not mentioned.
* Response: [NA]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided? The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review. Note: Need to refer to a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori published research objectives to score a yes.

* Quote: "A systematic review [according to PRISMA guidelines] was conducted using CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases. Article quality was assessed using MINORS criteria."
* Reasoning: The review was conducted according to PRISMA guidelines, which implies an 'a priori' design.
* Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? There should be at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements should be in place. Note: 2 people do study selection, 2 people do data extraction, consensus process or one person checks the others work.

* Quote: "Two reviewers (P.S.C., S.S.) performed the study selection, data extraction, and quality assessment processes independently and all data was recorded in tabular form electronically. Disagreements were resolved by discussion or consultation with the third reviewer/senior corresponding author who conceived the study (P.D.L.)."
* Reasoning: Two reviewers performed the study selection, data extraction, and quality assessment independently, and disagreements were resolved by discussion or consultation with a third reviewer.
* Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed? At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE). Key words and/or MESH terms must be stated and where feasible the search strategy should be provided. All searches should be supplemented by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found. Note: If at least 2 sources + one supplementary strategy used, select yes (Cochrane register/Central counts as 2 sources; a grey literature search counts as supplementary).

* Quote: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
* Reasoning: The review used at least two electronic sources (CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases) and supplemented the search by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.
* Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion? The authors should state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type. The authors should state whether or not they excluded any reports (from the systematic review), based on their publication status, language etc. Note: If review indicates that there was a search for grey literature or unpublished literature, indicate yes. SIGLE database, dissertations, conference proceedings, and trial registries are all considered grey for this purpose. If searching a source that contains both grey and non-grey, must specify that they were searching for grey/unpublished lit.

* Quote: "The search yielded no randomized trials, prospective cohort, or casecontrol studies valid to the aims of this review."
* Reasoning: The review did not explicitly state that they searched for grey literature, but it did search the conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade.
* Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided? A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select no.

* Quote: "Nineteen studies were included for systematic review."
* Reasoning: The review provided a list of included studies, but did not provide a list of excluded studies.
* Response: [No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided? In an aggregated form such as a table, data from the original studies should be provided on the participants, interventions and outcomes. The ranges of characteristics in all the studies analyzed e.g., age, race, sex, relevant socioeconomic data, disease status, duration, severity, or other diseases should be reported. Note: Acceptable if not in table format as long as they are described as above.

* Quote: "The 19 studies included in the initial search results were retrospective observational studies reported between years 1966 and 2014. These studies reported on patients with heterotaxy managed within centers located in North America (14), Asia (2), Austral-asia (1), Europe (1), and also from an international patient registry (1). Excluding those patients within the registry data, the number of individual patients reported within studies found that the majority of patients were from centers in the USA (N  683), followed by Canada (N  177), UK (N  92), and South Korea (N  67)."
* Reasoning: The review provided the characteristics of the included studies in the text.
* Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented? 'A priori' methods of assessment should be provided (e.g., for effectiveness studies if the author(s) chose to include only randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled studies, or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria); for other types of studies alternative items will be relevant. Note: Can include use of a quality scoring tool or checklist, e.g., Jadad scale, risk of bias, sensitivity analysis, etc., or a description of quality items, with some kind of result for EACH study (low or high is fine, as long as it is clear which studies scored low and which scored high; a summary score/range for all studies is not acceptable).

* Quote: "Quality of manuscripts was evaluated by using the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria, in addition for all sources of data by a local checklist (including reporting of symptoms, imaging, surgeries, morbidity, mortality, and so on). Bias was assessed at study and summary levels."
* Reasoning: The review used the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria to assess the scientific quality of the included studies.
* Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions? The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies. Cannot score yes for this question if scored no for question A7.

* Quote: "The evidence base for screening asymptomatic patients is weak especially considering the life-limiting comorbidities."
* Reasoning: The review considered the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating conclusions and explicitly stated the weakness of the evidence base for screening asymptomatic patients.
* Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate? For the pooled results, a test should be done to ensure the studies were combinable, to assess their homogeneity (i.e., Chi-squared test for homogeneity, I2 ). If heterogeneity exists a random effects model should be used and/or the clinical appropriateness of combining should be taken into consideration (i.e., is it sensible to combine?). Note: Indicate yes if they mention or describe heterogeneity, i.e., if they explain that they cannot pool because of heterogeneity/variability between interventions.

* Quote: "A meta-analysis was not formally undertaken other than cumulative totals and percentages of data included."
* Reasoning: The review did not perform a meta-analysis and did not assess the appropriateness of combining the findings of studies.
* Response: [NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed? An assessment of publication bias should include a combination of graphical aids (e.g., funnel plot, other available tests) and/or statistical tests (e.g., Egger regression test, Hedges-Olken). Note: If no test values or funnel plot included, score no. Score yes if mentions that publication bias could not be assessed because there were fewer than 10 included studies.

* Quote: "A meta-analysis was not formally undertaken other than cumulative totals and percentages of data included."
* Reasoning: The review did not perform a meta-analysis and did not assess publication bias.
* Response: [NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included? Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a yes, must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies.

* Quote: "No funding was sought or received for this work."
* Reasoning: The review did not indicate any sources of funding or support for the systematic review or the included studies.
* Response: [No]

PRISMA:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.

* Quote: "Is Screening of Intestinal Foregut Anatomy in Heterotaxy Patients Really Necessary? A Systematic Review in Search of the Evidence"
* Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a systematic review.
* Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

* Quote: "Objective: (1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in asymptomatic patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction? Summary of Background Data: Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis. Intestinal rotational anomalies are frequent among patients with heterotaxy, but debate exists as to whether they are benign in nature, requiring careful observation alone, or if surgical correction is warranted to prevent obstruction or midgut volvulus. Methods: A systematic review [according to PRISMA guidelines] was conducted using CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases. Article quality was assessed using MINORS criteria. Conference proceedings and unpublished data were screened additionally. Results: Nineteen studies met the eligibility criteria but reporting was adequate for 9. All were observational studies. These included a total of 414 patients managed expectantly, that is, asymptomatic patients in whom no intestinal rotation screening was undertaken (group A), 191 cases in whom screening was performed routinely (group B), and 92 patients considered symptomatic of potential rotational anomalies and therefore underwent imaging or laparotomy (group C). In group A, 1 patient developed symptoms attributable to malrotation in whom laparotomy confirmed the diagnosis (0.24%). Among groups B and C, 151 had Ladds operations (53%) and 14 cases of malrotation with obstruction or volvulus were described (4.9%), of which 2 symptomatic patients died before laparotomy. Overall surgical complication rate was 17% with 30-day mortality rate of 2.6% to 4.6%. Conclusion: The evidence base for screening asymptomatic patients is weak especially considering the life-limiting comorbidities."
* Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions and implications of key findings.
* Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

* Quote: "Objective: (1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in asymptomatic patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
* Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
* Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

* Quote: "Objective: (1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in asymptomatic patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
* Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
* Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

* Quote: "A local review protocol was established."
* Reasoning: The methods indicate that a local review protocol was established.
* Response: [Yes]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

* Quote: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
* Reasoning: The methods specify study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
* Response: [Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.

* Quote: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
* Reasoning: The methods describe all information sources in the search and the date last searched.
* Response: [Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

* Quote: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928)."
* Reasoning: The methods present the full electronic search strategy for at least one database.
* Response: [Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

* Quote: "Nineteen studies were included for systematic review."
* Reasoning: The methods state the process for selecting studies.
* Response: [Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

* Quote: "Two reviewers (P.S.C., S.S.) performed the study selection, data extraction, and quality assessment processes independently and all data was recorded in tabular form electronically. Disagreements were resolved by discussion or consultation with the third reviewer/senior corresponding author who conceived the study (P.D.L.)."
* Reasoning: The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
* Response: [Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

* Quote: "Quality of manuscripts was evaluated by using the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria, in addition for all sources of data by a local checklist (including reporting of symptoms, imaging, surgeries, morbidity, mortality, and so on)."
* Reasoning: The methods list and define all variables for which data were sought and any assumptions and simplifications made.
* Response: [Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

* Quote: "Quality of manuscripts was evaluated by using the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria, in addition for all sources of data by a local checklist (including reporting of symptoms, imaging, surgeries, morbidity, mortality, and so on). Bias was assessed at study and summary levels."
* Reasoning: The methods describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
* Response: [Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
